div.p:
Antonio:
So, to bring this back to alcohol and drugs… If I have a high tolerance, I may feel like it’s protecting me from having problems. But it reality, a high tolerance can make me less sensitive to the effects of alcohol, and lead me to believe I’m not at risk for problems, when I am. A person with low tolerance feels the effect and stops. A person with high tolerance does not feel it for a long time and keeps on drinking. By the time they realize they are impaired, it is often too late to protect themselves.

Online user 1:
I've always been proud of the fact that I had a high tolerance. I used to brag to everyone that I may be small but I can hold my liquor.

Online user 2:
Well, I have a low tolerance and I'm actually the one who's falling asleep on the couch after a few beers. But, a lot of my friends are able to drink a lot more than me and have a high tolerance. It's pretty scary, cause they're the ones I'm going to at the end of the night to drive me home.

Online user 3:
Well, you can't change your biology... I've always had a high tolerance.

Dorian:
I actually got a D.U.I. at Fort Belvoir just recently. I felt fine, I'd had a few drinks, I'd just come out of Germany, so my tolerance level was pretty high--I spent three years there. I felt fine, mentally, and physically I was acting fine, I left to drive. I got pulled over for doing a California roll at a stop sign--I just kinda slowed down a little bit, looked, then went ahead, but there happened to be a Virginia state police officer down the street who saw me do it. When they pulled me over, they had me do the field sobriety test. I performed fine on all those--no problems. Military policy on Fort Belvoir is that if you get pulled over during those hours, you're gonna get a breathalyzer. They took me to the station, and when I blew a breathalyzer, and I blew a .15, which is almost twice the legal limit, which was a surprise for me as well as some of the officers that were in the room, just because of the way I was acting. So, I got a D.U.I... There's no way getting out of that. It was crazy to blow a level that high but feel normal.

Antonio:
Yeah, okay… it’s understandable we might still believe having a high tolerance helps us, especially if we haven’t experienced problems yet. But let’s take a closer look at the pattern of how a high-tolerance can trick us into believing we’re not at risk for impairment problems.
